main-use-cases: As a knowledge base (including technical, non-fiction and encyclopaedic content)
share-wikis: Yes, and I am the only editor/administrator of my wiki(s)
value-of-tw: I dont use tiddlywiki at work. I use it to record discussions on our online book club in wiki form. In essence it is a traditional wiki.
tw-ability-level: I have customised TiddlyWiki through options and plugins;I have written custom HTML;I have written custom CSS styles
save-method: Single-file wiki through web browser with Download Saver (default saving mechanism)
backup-method: No automatic sync across my devices
wiki-setup-info:
Wiki Information

TiddlyWiki Version: 5.3.7
Current palette: $:/palettes/ABL-COLORS
Current theme: $:/themes/nico/notebook
Current layout: $:/core/ui/PageTemplate

Tiddler opening behaviour setting for navigations from within the story river: below

  $:/plugins/nico/notebook-mobile - 1.0.0
  $:/plugins/tiddlywiki/markdown - 5.3.7

  $:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla - 5.3.7
tw-customisations: I added a footer with custom images and CSS at the end of the html file.
project-strengths: It's extremely easy to start a wiki. Having the whole wiki in a single file is perfect. No need to run and maintain a server. These are the best things about tiddlywiki.
project-weaknesses:
I researched "wiki engines" a year or so ago and did not pick tiddlywiki in part because I felt disoriented by the navigation style  - things changing the layout of the site all the time. This made me discard tiddlywiki as an option, probably more people do it too

I'm affraid Tiddlywiki is not suported in older or future browsers since it uses lots of javascript.

It feels tiddlywiki is quite complete, tbh. I don't see how could I contribute work to the project. I can donate money, though.
ok-to-publish: Yes, I am happy for my responses to be published
title: Community Survey 2025 Answer 00153
